data.name: heading
data.body: Inductance

data.name: paragraph
data.body: When a coil experiences a change in the magnetic field around it, it can induce an electric current within itself or in another nearby coil. This occurs whether the change in magnetic field is due to another coil nearby or due to a change in current within the same coil. Let's explore these scenarios further.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: In this scenario, a coil induces an electric current within itself due to a change in the magnetic flux around it. This change in flux is directly proportional to the current flowing through the coil. If the coil's geometry remains constant over time, the rate of change of magnetic flux ($\frac{d\Phi}{dt}$) is proportional to the rate of change of current ($\frac{dI}{dt}$):

data.name: expression
data.body: \[\frac{d\Phi}{dt} \propto \frac{dI}{dt}  \quad \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Each turn in a closely wound coil contributes to the induced electromotive force (EMF) when the magnetic flux ($\Phi_B$) changes. The total magnetic flux linked with all turns of the coil is termed as flux linkage, represented by $N\Phi_B$. For a closely wound coil, the flux linkage ($N\Phi_B$) is directly proportional to the current ($I$):

data.name: expression
data.body: \[N\Phi_B \propto I \quad \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The constant of proportionality in this relation is called inductance. Inductance depends solely on the geometry of the coil and its intrinsic material properties, similar to how capacitance depends on the geometry and material properties of a capacitor.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Inductance is a scalar quantity with dimensions of $[M L^2 T^{-2} A^{-2}]$, obtained by dividing the dimensions of flux by the dimensions of current. Its SI unit is the henry (H), named in honor of Joseph Henry, who independently discovered electromagnetic induction in the USA.

data.name: bold
data.body: Mutual inductance

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Consider two long co-axial solenoids depicted in the figure, each having a length $l$. Let's denote the radius of the inner solenoid $S_1$ by $r_1$ and the number of turns per unit length by $n_1$. Similarly, for the outer solenoid $S_2$, we have $r_2$ and $n_2$ respectively. Let $N_1$ and $N_2$ represent the total number of turns of coils $S_1$ and $S_2$ respectively.

data.name: paragraph

data.name: paragraph
data.body: From equations (4) and (7), we observe $M_{12} = M_{21} = M$. This equality holds for long co-axial solenoids. If the inner solenoid were much shorter than (and placed well inside) the outer solenoid, we could still calculate the flux linkage $N_1\Phi_1$ because the inner solenoid would be effectively immersed in a uniform magnetic field due to the outer solenoid. However, it would be extremely challenging to calculate the flux linkage with the outer solenoid as the magnetic field due to the inner solenoid would vary across the length and cross-section of the outer solenoid. Therefore, the calculation of $M_{21}$ would also be extremely difficult in such scenarios. The equality $M_{12} = M_{21}$ is valuable in such situations.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: This discussion has been presented assuming air as the medium within the solenoids. If a medium of relative permeability $\mu_r$ had been present, the mutual inductance would be:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ M = \mu_r \mu_0 n_1 n_2 \pi r_1^2 l \quad  \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: It's also essential to note that the mutual inductance of a pair of coils, solenoids, etc., depends on their separation and relative orientation.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: When a current through coil $C_2$ changes, an EMF is induced in coil $C_1$. Let $\Phi_1$ be the flux through coil $C_1$ (with $N_1$ turns) when the current in coil $C_2$ is $I_2$. We have:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: For currents varying with time:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: \[ \frac{d(N_1\Phi_1)}{dt} = \frac{d(MI_2)}{dt} \quad \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Since the induced EMF in coil $C_1$ is given by:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: \[ \varepsilon_1 = -\frac{d(N_1\Phi_1)}{dt} \quad  \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: We obtain:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: \[ \varepsilon = -M\frac{dI_2}{dt} \quad \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: This equation illustrates that varying current in a coil can induce EMF in a neighboring coil. The magnitude of the induced EMF depends on the rate of change of current and the mutual inductance of the two coils.

data.name: bold
data.body: Self-Inductance

data.name: paragraph
data.body: In the preceding sub-section, we examined how the flux in one solenoid can influence the current in another. However, it's also possible for an electromotive force (emf) to be induced in a single isolated coil due to a change in flux through the coil caused by varying the current through the same coil. This phenomenon is termed self-induction. In this scenario, the flux linkage through a coil of $N$ turns is directly proportional to the current through the coil and is expressed as:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ N \Phi_B \propto I \quad \]\[ N \Phi_B = L I \quad \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Here, the constant of proportionality $L$ is called the self-inductance of the coil, also known as the coefficient of self-induction. When the current varies, the flux linked with the coil also changes, inducing an emf in the coil. The induced emf is given by:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \varepsilon = \frac{d(N\Phi_B)}{dt} \quad \]

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \varepsilon = -L \frac{dI}{dt} \quad \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Thus, the self-induced emf always opposes any change (increase or decrease) of current in the coil.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: It is possible to calculate the self-inductance for circuits with simple geometries. Let's calculate the self-inductance of a long solenoid of cross-sectional area $A$ and length $l$, having $n$ turns per unit length. The magnetic field due to a current $I$ flowing in the solenoid is $B = \mu_0 n I$ (neglecting edge effects, as before). The total flux linked with the solenoid is:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ N\Phi_B = (nl)(\mu nI)(A) \quad \]\[ = \mu n^2 AlI \quad \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: where $nl$ represents the total number of turns. Thus, the self-inductance is given by:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ L = \frac{N\Phi}{I} \quad \]\[ = \mu n^2 Al \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: If we fill the inside of the solenoid with a material of relative permeability $\mu_r$ (for example, soft iron, which has a high value of relative permeability), then:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ L = \mu_r \mu_0 n^2 Al \quad \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The self-inductance of the coil depends on its geometry and on the permeability of the medium.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The self-induced emf is also called the back emf as it opposes any change in the current in a circuit. Physically, self-inductance plays the role of inertia. It is the electromagnetic analogue of mass in mechanics.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: So, work needs to be done against the back emf ($\varepsilon$) in establishing the current. This work done is stored as magnetic potential energy. For the current $I$ at an instant in a circuit, the rate of work done is given by:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \frac{dW}{dt} = |\varepsilon| I \quad  \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: If we ignore the resistive losses and consider only the inductive effect, then using:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \frac{dW}{dt} = LI \frac{dI}{dt} \quad  \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The total amount of work done in establishing the current $I$ is:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ W = \int dW = \int_0^l L I dI \quad  \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Thus, the energy required to build up the current $I$ is:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ W = \frac{1}{2}LI^2 \quad  \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: This expression reminds us of $mv^2/2$ for the (mechanical) kinetic energy of a particle of mass $m$, and shows that $L$ is analogous to $m$ (i.e., $L$ is electrical inertia and opposes the growth and decay of current in the circuit).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Consider the general case of currents flowing simultaneously in two nearby coils. The flux linked with one coil will be the sum of two fluxes which exist independently. Equation (EQ 5) would be modified into:

data.name: paragraph
data.body: where $M_{11}$ represents inductance due to the same coil.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: Therefore, using Faraday’s law:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \varepsilon_1 = M_{11} \frac{dI_1}{dt} - M_{12} \frac{dI_2}{dt} \quad \]

data.name: paragraph
data.body: $M_{11}$ is the self-inductance and is written as $L_1$. Therefore:

data.name: expression
data.body: \[ \varepsilon_1 = L_1 \frac{dI_1}{dt} - M_{12} \frac{dI_2}{dt} \quad \]
